description: Coined by American humorist Gelett Burgess in 1907 on a dust jacket at a trade association dinner in 1907. The dust jacket said “YES, this is a “BLURB”!” and featured a (fictitious) “Miss Belinda Blurb” shown calling out, described as “in the act of blurbing”.

entries.meaning: A short description of a book, film, or other work, written and used for promotional purposes.

verbs.description: blurb (third-person singular simple present blurbs, present participle blurbing, simple past and past participle blurbed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To write or quote in a blurb.

examples: Edward R. Murrow and other leading radio personalities blurbed the book, published in 1950 by Oxford University Press, and Siepmann thanked Paul Lazarsfeld and Herta Herzog in his acknowledgments.
